\end{aligned}
$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing angle $= a$

As the triangle is an isosceles triangle, the third angle $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a  + a + 96                             &= 180   \\\\
2a + 96                                 &= 180  \\\\
2a                                      &= 180 - 96  \\\\
2a                                      &= 84  \\\\
a                                       &= \dfrac {84} {2}  \\\\
a                                       &= \dfrac {42 \times 2} {2}  \\\\
a                                       &= \dfrac {42 \times \cancel{2}}{\cancel{2}}   \\\\
a                                       &= 42  \degree
\end{aligned}
$

Missing angle $= 42  \degree$

- Deal A: Take $25 \%$ off any purchase!
- Deal B: Sale Price $\pounds 205$

solutionDetails.working:
Let's calculate the sale price of bicycle from each deal.

**Deal A**

If the price is reduced by $25 \%$, then the sale price will be $100 - 25 = 75 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Sale price from Deal A}     &= 75 \% \ \text{of} \ 260 \\\\
                                  &= \dfrac {75} {100} \times 260   \\\\
                                  &= \dfrac {75 \times 260 } {100}  \\\\
                                  &= \dfrac {25 \times 3 \times 4 \times 65 } {25 \times 4}  \\\\
                                  &= \dfrac {\cancel{25} \times 3 \times \cancel{4} \times 65 } {\cancel{25}  \times \cancel{4}}   \\\\
                                  &= 3 \times 65 \\\\
                                  &= \pounds 195
\end{aligned}
$

**Deal B**

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Sale price from Deal B}     &= \pounds 205
\end{aligned}
$

Better deal $= \text{Deal A} = \pounds 195$

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Baldwin ran}     &= 7 \times 2 + 1 \times 1 \\\\
                       &= 15 \ \text{km} \\\\
 \text{Jeff ran}       &= 3 \times 2 \\\\
                       &= 6 \ \text{km} \\\\
\text{Difference}      &= 15 - 6 \\\\
                       &= 9 \ \text{km}
\end{aligned}
$

Baldwin ran $9 \ \text{km}$ more than Jeff.

questions.prompt:
There are $14$ boys in year $4$.

Given that $\dfrac{2}{5}$ of the year are boys, how many are girls?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the total number of students in year $4 = a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{2}{5} \times a                          &= 14  \\\\
\dfrac{2 \times a}{5}                          &= 14  \\\\
a                                              &= \dfrac{14 \times 5}{2} \\\\
                                               &= \dfrac{7 \times 2 \times 5}{2} \\\\
                                               &= \dfrac{7 \times \cancel{2} \times 5}{\cancel{2}} \\\\
                                               &= 7 \times 5 \\\\
                                               &= 35
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Total children}   &= 35 \\\\
\text{Total girls}      &= \text{Total children} - \text{Total boys} \\\\
                        &= 35 - 14  \\\\
                        &= 21
\end{aligned}
$

children.prompt:
I am thinking of a number.

If I add $5$ to it and then divide by $2$, I get $6$.

What number am I thinking of?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {a + 5} { 2}    &= 6 \\\\
a + 5                  &= 6 \times 2 \\\\
a + 5                  &= 12 \\\\
a                      &= 12 - 5 \\\\
a                      &= 7
\end{aligned}
$

The number I am thinking of $= 7$

The number of students absent from Year $7$ was recorded as follows.

| Monday | Tuesday | Wednesday | Thursday | Friday |
|:------:|:-------:|:---------:|:--------:|:------:|
| $4$    | $6$     | $5$       | $3$      | $?$    |

If the **mean number** of students absent that week from Year $7$ was $4$, how many students were absent on Friday?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of students absent on Friday $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {4 + 6 + 5 + 3 + a} {5}          &= 4 \\\\
\dfrac {18 + a} {5}                     &= 4 \\\\
18 + a                                  &= 4 \times 5 \\\\
18 + a                                  &= 20 \\\\
a                                       &= 20 - 18 \\\\
a                                       &= 2
\end{aligned}
$

Number of students absent on Friday $= 2$

questions.prompt:
Gino is thinking of a number.

If he

- halves it,
- then adds $5$ to it
- and then squares it and gets $121$.

Circle the number that Gino was thinking of.

$12 \quad 17 \quad 32$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number Gino thought of $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\bigg(\dfrac{a}{2} + 5 \bigg)^2     &= 121 \\\\
\dfrac{a}{2} + 5                    &= \sqrt{121} \\\\
\dfrac{a}{2} + 5                    &= 11 \\\\
\dfrac{a}{2}                        &= 11 - 5 \\\\
a                                   &= 2 \times (11 - 5) \\\\
a                                   &= 2 \times 6 \\\\
a                                   &= 12
\end{aligned}
$

The number that Gino thought of $= 12$.

children.prompt:
The entry prices at a theme park are

|                  | Price                 |
|:-----------:     |:---------------------:|
|   Adults         |   $\pounds 6.25$ each |
|   Children       |   $\pounds 2.50$ each |

Find the cost for $2$ adults and $4$ children to visit the theme park.

The entry prices for a group are

|                  | Price                 |
|:-----------:     |:---------------------:|
|   Adults         |   $\pounds 5.00$ each |
|   Children       |   $\pounds 3.00$ each |

A group of adults and children goes to the theme park for a cost of $\pounds 44$.

There are $4$ adults in the group.
How many children are in the group?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of children $= c$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
4 \times 5 + c \times 3       &= 44 \\\\
20 + 3c                       &= 44 \\\\
3c                            &= 44 - 20 \\\\
3c                            &= 24 \\\\
c                             &= \dfrac {24} {3} \\\\
c                             &= \dfrac {3 \times 8} {3} \\\\
c                             &= \dfrac {\cancel 3 \times 8} {\cancel 3} \\\\
c                             &= 8
\end{aligned}
$

Number of children $= 8$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the weight of a small can (in $\text{grams}$) $= w$


$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Total weight} &= 1.25 \ \text{kg}\\\\
                    &= 1.25 \times 1000 \ \text{grams} \\\\
                    &= 1250 \ \text{grams}

$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
425 + 3w              &= 1250  \\\\
3w                    &= 1250 - 425  \\\\
3w                    &= 825  \\\\
w                     &= \dfrac{825}{3}  \\\\
w                     &= \dfrac{275 \times 3} {3}  \\\\
w                     &= \dfrac{275 \times \cancel 3} {\cancel 3}  \\\\
w                     &= 275 \ \text{grams}
\end{aligned}
$

Weight of a small can $= 275 \ \text{grams}$

questions.prompt:
There are $24$ pupils in $7\text{S}$.

Two thirds of them are boys.

Half of the boys have brown hair.

How many of pupils in $7\text{S}$ are boys with brown hair?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of boys $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of boys}      &= \dfrac {2} {3} \times 24 \\\\
a                          &= \dfrac {2 \times 24} {3} \\\\
a                          &= \dfrac {2 \times 8 \times 3} {3} \\\\
a                          &= \dfrac {2 \times 8 \times \cancel 3} {\cancel 3} \\\\
a                          &= 2 \times 8 \\\\
a                          &= 16
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Boys with brown hair}       &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times a\\\\
                                  &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times 16 \\\\
                                  &= 8
\end{aligned}
$

questions.prompt:
The table shows Ann's marks in two tests.

|       Test    | Marks             |
|:-----------:    |:---------------------:|
|   $1$       |   $60$ out of $80$ |
|   $2$       |   $70$ out of $100$ |

In which test did Ann do better? You **must** show your working.

solutionDetails.working:
Let's calculate the percentage score for both the tests.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Test } 1       &= \dfrac {60}{80} \times 100 \\\\
                     &= \dfrac {60 \times 100}{80} \\\\
                     &= \dfrac {15 \times 4 \times 20 \times 5}{20 \times 4} \\\\
                     &= \dfrac {15 \times \cancel{4} \times \cancel{20} \times 5}{\cancel{20} \times \cancel{4}} \\\\
                     &= 15 \times 5 \\\\
                     &= 75 \% \\\\
\text{Test } 2       &= \dfrac {70}{100} \times 100 \\\\
                     &= 70 \%
\end{aligned}
$

Ann did better in Test $1$.
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.
- Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).

questions.prompt:
The water cooler in the staff room contains $5 \ \text{litres}$ of water.

How many $200 \ \text{ml}$ glasses of water can it fill before it needs replacing?

solutionDetails.working:
The capacity of cooler is given in litres and capacity of glasses is given ml. Let's convert capacity of cooler in ml.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Total water}       &= 5 \ \text{litres} \\\\
                         &= 5 \times 1000 \ \text{ml} \\\\
                         &= 5000 \ \text{ml}
\end{aligned}
$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of glasses} &= \dfrac {\text{Total Water in cooler}} {\text{Water in a glass}} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {5000} {200} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {200 \times 25} {200} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {\cancel {200} \times 25} {\cancel {200}} \\\\
                         &= 25
\end{aligned}
$

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
l \times w          &= 36 \\\\
2 \times (l + w)    & = 26 \\\\
l + w               &= \dfrac {26}{2} \\\\
l + w               &= \dfrac {13 \times 2}{2} \\\\
l + w               &= \dfrac {13 \times \cancel 2}{\cancel 2} \\\\
l + w               &= 13
\end{aligned}
$

We can easily infer the values by using trial and error. Let's find out $2$ numbers which meets the following critiera based on the equations above.

- Both the numbers should be smaller than $13$
- The product of the $2$ numbers is $36$
- The sum of the $2$ numbers is $13$.

Factors of $36 = 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 9, 12, 18, 36$

| Factors   |  Sum  | Numbers $< 13$    |
|:-------:  |:----: |:---------------:  |
| $2, 18$   | $20$  |        No         |
| $3, 12$   | $15$  |       Yes         |
| $4, 9$    | $13$  |       Yes         |

A quick check shows that $4$ and $9$ meets all the criteria above.

*Note: The two equations form a quadratic equation. rtq_abbr_md_quadratic_note*

Width of the rectangle $= 4 \ \text{cm}$

Length of the rectangle $= 9 \ \text{cm}$

children.prompt:
The number of boys who fail the test is $15$.

How many boys pass the test?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the total number of boys $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {3} {12} \times a            &= 15 \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {15 \times 12} {3} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {3 \times 5 \times 12} {3} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {\cancel {3} \times 5 \times 12} {\cancel {3}} \\\\
a                                   &= 5 \times 12 \\\\
a                                   &= 60
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Students who passed}  &= a - 15 \\\\
                            &= 60 - 15 \\\\
                            &= 45
\end{aligned}
$

questions.prompt:
If $2$ apples and $1$ banana cost $\pounds 1.20$

and

$1$ apple and $2$ bananas cost $\pounds 1.35$, find the cost of an apple and a banana separately.
questions.answer:
Cost of an apple $= \pounds 0.35$

Cost of a banana $= \pounds 0.50$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the cost of an apple $= a$

Let the cost of a banana $= b$


As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
2a + b &=  1.20 \\\\
a + 2b &= 1.35
\end{aligned}
$

We have got $2$ variables and we have $2$ equations to solve them. Let's eliminate to reduce it to just one variable.

Multiply the second equation by $2$.

$
\begin{aligned}
2 \times a + 2 \times 2b     &= 2 \times 1.35 \\\\
2a + 4b                      &= 2.70
\end{aligned}
$

Subtract the first equation from the second to reduce it to one variable.

$
\begin{aligned}
2a + 4b - (2a + b)     &= 2.70 - 1.20 \\\\
2a + 4b -2a  -b        &= 1.50 \\\\
3b                     &= 1.50 \\\\
b                      &= \dfrac {1.50} {3} \\\\
b                      &= \pounds 0.50
\end{aligned}
$

Cost of a banana $= \pounds 0.50$

Let's substitute the value of $b$ in one of the initial equations to find the cost of an apple.

$
\begin{aligned}
2a + b     &=  1.20 \\\\
2a + 50    &=  1.20 \\\\
2a         &=  1.20 - 0.50 \\\\
2a         &=  0.70 \\\\
a          &= \dfrac {0.70} {2} \\\\
a          &= \pounds 0.35
\end{aligned}
$

Cost of an apple $= \pounds 0.35$

At which shop is the price of the two chairs the cheapest?

You **must** show your working.

solutionDetails.working:
Let's calculate the cheapest price of $2$ chairs from each shop.

**Shop A**

If the price is reduced by $30 \%$, then the sale price will be $100 - 30 = 70 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of 2 chairs from Shop A}     &= 70\% \times 600 \times 2 \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac{70}{100}  \times 600 \times 2  \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac{70 \times 600 \times 2}{100} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac{70 \times 6 \cancel{0} \cancel{0} \times 2}{1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} \\\\
                                        &= 70 \times 6 \times 2 \\\\
                                        &= \pounds 840
\end{aligned}
$

**Shop B**

If the price is reduced by $\dfrac{1}{5}$, then the sale price will be $1 - \dfrac{1}{5} = \dfrac{4}{5}$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of } 2 \text{ chairs from Shop B}    &= \dfrac{4}{5} \times 550 \times 2 \\\\
                                                &= \dfrac{4 \times 550 \times 2}{5} \\\\
                                                &= \dfrac{4 \times 5 \times 110 \times 2}{5} \\\\
                                                &= \dfrac{4 \times \cancel{5} \times 110 \times 2}{\cancel{5}} \\\\
                                                &= 4 \times 110 \times 2 \\\\
                                                &= \pounds 880
\end{aligned}
$

**Shop C**

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of } 2 \text{ chairs from Shop C}     &= \pounds 820
\end{aligned}
$


Cheapest price $= \text{Shop C} = \pounds 820$

questions.prompt:
Sophie and her friends decided to raise money for charity by baking and selling cookies.
They set themselves a target of $\pounds 200$ profit to raise.

Each cookie cost them $10 \ \text{p}$ to make and they sold them for $50 \ \text{p}$.

How many cookies did they need to sell to reach their target?

solutionDetails.working:
The cookie cost is given in pence and the target is given in pounds. Let's convert the target into pence.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Total target}                     &= \pounds 200 \\\\
                                         &= 200 \times 100 \ \text{p} \\\\
                                         &= 20000 \ \text{p} \\\\
\text {Cost of each cookie}              &= 10 \ \text{p} \\\\
\text {Sale Price for each cookie}       &= 50 \ \text{p} \\\\
\text {Profit per cookie}                &= 50 - 10 \\\\
                                         &= 40 \ \text{p}
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Number of cookies needed}             &= \dfrac {\text {Total target}} {\text {Profit per cookie}} \\\\
                                             &= \dfrac {20000} {40} \\\\
                                             &= \dfrac {40 \times 500} {40} \\\\
                                             &= \dfrac {\cancel {40} \times 500} {\cancel {40}} \\\\
                                             &= 500
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**


Let the number of cookies $= c$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}

$

questions.prompt: If Tom is half his mum's age and together their ages add up to $72$, how old is Tom?

solutionDetails.working:
Let Tom's age $= a$

Tom's mum's age $=2a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a + 2a      &= 72 \\\\
3a          &= 72 \\\\
a           &= \dfrac {72} {3} \\\\
a           &= \dfrac {24 \times 3} {3} \\\\
a           &= \dfrac {24 \times \cancel{3}} {\cancel{3}} \\\\
a           &= 24 \ \text{years}
\end{aligned}
$

Tom's age $= 24 \ \text{years}$

questions.prompt: I wish to cover a wall measuring $2 \ \text{m}$ by $6 \ \text{m}$ in tiles which are each $50 \ \text{cm}$ by $50 \ \text{cm}$.

children.prompt: How many tiles will I need?

solutionDetails.working:
The wall measurement is given in $\text{meters}$ while the tile measurement is given in $\text{cm}$.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Number of tiles}  &= \dfrac {\text{Area of the wall}} {\text{Area of a tile}} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {2 \ \text{m} \times 6 \ \text{m}} {50 \ \text{cm} \times 50 \ \text{cm}} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {2 \times 100 \ \text{cm} \times 6 \times 100 \ \text{cm}} {50 \ \text{cm} \times 50 \ \text{cm}} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {2 \times 100 \times 6 \times 100} {50  \times 50} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {2 \times 50 \times 2 \times 6 \times 50 \times 2} {50  \times 50} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {2 \times \cancel{50} \times 2 \times 6 \times \cancel{50} \times 2} {\cancel{50}  \times \cancel{50}} \\\\
                         &= 2 \times 2 \times 6 \times 2 \\\\
                         &= 48
\end{aligned}
$

children.prompt: If I now choose to use tiles which are $40 \ \text{cm}$ by $20 \ \text{cm}$ how many of these smaller tiles will I need?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of tiles}  &= \dfrac {\text{Area of the wall}} {\text{Area of a tile}} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \ \text{m} \times 6 \ \text{m}} {40 \ \text{cm} \times 20 \ \text{cm}} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \times 100  \ \text{cm} \times 6 \times 100 \ \text{cm}} {40 \ \text{cm} \times 20 \ \text{cm}} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \times 100 \times 6 \times 100} {40  \times 20} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \times 5 \times 20 \times 6 \times 5 \times 20} {2 \times 20  \times 20} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {\cancel{2} \times 5 \times \cancel{20} \times 6 \times 5 \times \cancel{20}} {\cancel{2} \times \cancel{20}  \times \cancel{20}} \\\\
                        &= 5 \times 6 \times 5 \\\\
                        &= 150
\end{aligned}
$

children.prompt:
I am thinking of a number.

If I add $6$ then double it I get $46$.

What number am I thinking of?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
(a + 6) \times 2            &= 46 \\\\
a + 6                       &= \dfrac {46} {2} \\\\
a + 6                       &= \dfrac {23 \times 2} {2} \\\\
a + 6                       &= \dfrac {23 \times \cancel {2}} {\cancel {2}} \\\\
a + 6                       &= 23 \\\\
a                           &= 23 - 6 \\\\
a                           &= 17
\end{aligned}
$

The number I am thinking of $= 17$

$36$ students chose hockey.

How many students chose swimming?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the total number of students in 6C $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{60}{360} \times a        &= 36 \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac{36 \times 360}{60} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac{36 \times 60 \times 6}{60} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac{36 \times \cancel{60} \times 6}{\cancel{60}} \\\\
a                               &= 36 \times 6 \\\\
a                               &= 216
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Students who chose swimming}  &= \dfrac{90}{360} \times a \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac{90}{360} \times 216 \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac{90 \times 216}{360}  \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac{90 \times 4 \times 54}{90 \times 4}  \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac{\cancel{90}  \times \cancel{4} \times 54}{\cancel{90} \times \cancel{4}} \\\\
                                    &= 54
\end{aligned}
$

solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Tree height after second year}  &= \dfrac {125} {100} \times \dfrac {130} {100} \times 180 \\\\
                                       &= \dfrac {125 \times 130 \times 180} {100 \times 100} \\\\
                                       &= \dfrac {125 \times 13\cancel{0} \times 18\cancel{0}} {100 \times 1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} \\\\
                                       &= \dfrac {125 \times 13 \times 18} {100} \\\\
                                       &= \dfrac {29250} {100} \\\\
                                       &= 292.5 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

Tree height at the end of the second year $= 292.5$ cm.

solutionDetails.working:
Let the side of the square garden (in $\text{m}$) $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a \times a                          &= 81 \\\\
a^2                                 &= 81 \\\\
a                                   &= \sqrt{81} \\\\
a                                   &= 9 \ \text{m}
\end{aligned}
$

** INFER_DESCRIPTION_NEEDS_IMPROVMENT_STARTS The $4$ corners will be counted twice, so ensure we account for that in the final calculation INFER_DESCRIPTION_NEEDS_IMPROVMENT_ENDS **

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of posts needed}          &= 4 \times 9 - 4 \\\\
                                       &= 36 - 4 \\\\
                                       &= 32
\end{aligned}
$

questions.prompt:
George had a bag full of $24$ apples.

-  He gave half of them to his Granny to make an apple pie.
-  He gave two thirds of what was left to his friends and then put the rest in the fruit bowl.

How many did he put in the fruit bowl?

solutionDetails.working:
If George gave $\dfrac {1} {2}$ to his Granny, then he is left with $1 - \dfrac {1} {2} = \dfrac {1} {2}$ of the apples. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Apples left}     &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times 24 \\\\
                        &= 12
\end{aligned}
$

If George gave $\dfrac {2} {3}$ to his friends, then he is left with $1 - \dfrac {2} {3} = \dfrac {1} {3}$ of the remaining apples. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Apples left in the fruit bowl}     &= \dfrac {1} {3} \times 12 \\\\
                                          &= 4
\end{aligned}
$

Number of apples left in his fruit bowl $= 4$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**


$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Apples left in the fruit bowl} &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times \dfrac {1} {3} \times 24 \\\\
                                      &= \dfrac {24} {2 \times 3} \\\\
                                      &= \dfrac {4 \times 2 \times 3} {2 \times 3} \\\\
                                      &= \dfrac {4 \times \cancel{2} \times \cancel{3}} {\cancel{2} \times \cancel{3}} \\\\
                                      &= 4
\end{aligned}
$

Number of apples left in the fruit bowl $= 4$

questions.prompt:
Emilie is thinking of a number. If she

-  adds $2$ to it,
-  then squares it
-  and then subtracts $4$ she gets $60$.

Circle the number that Emilie was thinking of.

$4 \quad 6 \quad 30$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number Emilie thought of $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
(a + 2 ) ^ {2} - 4     &= 60 \\\\
(a + 2 ) ^ {2}         &= 60 + 4 \\\\
(a + 2 ) ^ {2}         &= 64 \\\\
a + 2                  &= \sqrt {64} \\\\
a + 2                  &= 8 \\\\
a                      &= 8 - 2 \\\\
a                      &= 6
\end{aligned}
$

Number that Emilie thought is $= 6$.

questions.prompt:
Freya scored $16$ out of $20$ in her spelling test. Hannah scored $85 \%$ in her spelling test.

Who did better? You must explain your answer.

solutionDetails.working:
Let's calculate the percentage score for both.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Freya's score}      &= \dfrac {16} {20} \times 100 \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {16 \times 100} {20} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {16 \times 5 \times 20} {20} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {16 \times 5 \times \cancel{20}} {\cancel{20}} \\\\
                           &= 16 \times 5 \\\\
                           &= 80 \% \\\\
\text {Hannah's score}     &= 85 \%
\end{aligned}
$

From the calculation above, Hannah did better than Freya.

children.prompt: Given that $5$ people owned a white car, how many people owned a silver car?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the total number of people $= a$

As per the graph,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {30} {360} \times a          &= 5 \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {5 \times 360} {30} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {5 \times 12 \times 30} {30} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {5 \times 12 \times \cancel {30}} {\cancel {30}} \\\\
a                                   &= 5 \times 12 \\\\
a                                   &= 60
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {People who own silver car}   &= \dfrac {180} {360} \times a \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {180} {360} \times 60 \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {180 \times 60} {360} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {180 \times 2 \times 30} {2 \times 180} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {\cancel {180} \times \cancel {2} \times 30} {\cancel {2} \times \cancel {180}} \\\\
                                    &= 30
\end{aligned}
$

questions.prompt:
Jeff has $8$ pizzas to share between himself and his friends.

If each person is to get $\dfrac{2}{3}$ of a pizza how many friends can he feed?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of persons}    &= \dfrac {\text{Total pizzas}} {\text{Pizza per person}} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {8} { \dfrac {2} {3}} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {8 \times 3} { 2} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {4 \times 2 \times 3} {2} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {4 \times \cancel{2} \times 3} {\cancel{2}} \\\\
                            &= 4 \times 3 \\\\
                            &= 12 \\\\
\text{Number of friends}    &= 12 - 1 \\\\
                            &= 11
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**


Using ratio,

$
\begin{array}{cccccccccccccc}
  & \text{pizzas}                                                           &:& \text{persons} \\\\
= & \dfrac{2}{3}                                                            &:& 1 \\\\
= & \dfrac{2}{3} \times \dfrac{3}{2}                                        &:& 1 \times \dfrac{3}{2} \\\\
= & 1                                                                       &:& \dfrac{3}{2} \\\\
= & 1 \times 8                                                              &:& \dfrac{3 \times 8}{2} \\\\
= & 8                                                                       &:& \dfrac{3 \times 4 \times 2}{2} \\\\
= & 8                                                                       &:& \dfrac{3 \times 4 \times \cancel{2}}{\cancel{2}} \\\\
= & 8                                                                       &:& 12
\end{array}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of persons}    &= 12 \\\\
\text{Number of friends}    &= 12 - 1 \\\\
                            &= 11
\end{aligned}
$


---

**Alternative working 2**


Let the number of persons $= a$

Using equivalent ratio,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{2}{3} \text{ pizzas} : 1 \text{ people}  &= 8 \text{ pizzas} : a \text{ persons} \\\\
\dfrac{2}{3 \times 1}                           &= \dfrac {8} {a} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {8 \times 3} { 2} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {4 \times 2 \times 3} {2} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {4 \times \cancel{2} \times 3} {\cancel{2}} \\\\
a                                               &= 4 \times 3 \\\\
a                                               &= 12
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of persons}    &= 12 \\\\
\text{Number of friends}    &= 12 - 1 \\\\
                            &= 11
\end{aligned}
$

questions.prompt:
The following is a recipe for making $12$ cupcakes.

$200 \ \text{g}$ caster sugar

$200 \ \text{g}$ butter

$180 \ \text{g}$ flour

$2$ eggs

children.prompt: Isaac wants to make $36$ cupcakes. How much flour should he use?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the amount of flour used $= a$

Using equivalent ratio,

$
\begin{aligned}
12 \ \text{cupcakes} : 180 \ \text{grams}       &= 36 \ \text{cupcakes} : a \ \text{grams} \\\\
\dfrac{12} {180}                                &= \dfrac {36} {a} \\\\
12 \times a                                     &= 36 \times 180 \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {36 \times 180} {12} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {3 \times 12 \times 180} {12} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {3 \times \cancel {12} \times 180} {\cancel {12}} \\\\
a                                               &= 3 \times 180 \\\\
a                                               &= 540 \ \text{g}
\end{aligned}
$

Flour used $= 540 \ \text{g}$

children.prompt:
Lucy has $1  \ \text{kg}$ of caster sugar.

Given that she had plenty of all the other ingredients, how many cupcakes can she make?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of cupcakes she can make $= a$

Using equivalent ratio,

$
\begin{aligned}
200 \ \text{g} : 12 \ \text{cupcakes}           &= 1 \ \text{kg} : a \ \text{cupcakes} \\\\
\dfrac {200 \ \text{g}} {12}                    &= \dfrac {1 \ \text{kg}} {a} \\\\
\dfrac {200 \ \text{g}} {12}                    &= \dfrac {1000 \ \text{g}} {a} \\\\
200 \times a                                    &= 1000 \times 12 \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {1000 \times 12} {200} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {200 \times 5 \times 12} {200} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {\cancel {200} \times 5 \times 12} {\cancel {200}} \\\\
a                                               &= 5 \times 12 \\\\
a                                               &= 60
\end{aligned}
$

Number of cupcakes $= 60$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**


Using ratios,

$
\begin{array}{cccccccccccccc}
  & \text{caster sugar}             &:& \text{cupcakes} \\\\
= & 200 \ \text{g}                  &:& 12 \\\\
= & 200  \times 5                   &:& 12 \times 5 \\\\
= & 1000 \ \text{g}                 &:& 60 \\\\
= & 1 \ \text{kg}                   &:& 60
\end{array}
$

Number of cupcakes $= 60$

solutionDetails.working:

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {a} {18} + \dfrac {1} {18}     &= \dfrac {1} {2} \\\\
\dfrac {a} {18} + \dfrac {1} {18}     &= \dfrac {1 \times 9} {2 \times 9} \\\\
\dfrac {a + 1} {18}                   &= \dfrac {9} {18} \\\\
a + 1                                 &= 9 \\\\
a                                     &= 9 - 1 \\\\
a                                     &= 8
\end{aligned}
$

Have a look at the deals ticket vendors are offering:

Each ticket cost $\pounds 480$.

|     Offers    |                                     |
|:-------------:|:-----------------------------------:|
| Super Tickets |         Buy $2$ get $1$ free        |
|  Tickets R US | Buy $3$ get $25 \%$ off total price |
| Ticket Galore |    Buy $1$ get $2$ at $40 \%$ off   |
|   Top Ticket  |      Buy $2$ get $1$ half price     |


<svg width="260" height="160" viewBox="0 0 260 160" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Triangle">
  <polygon points="40,130 220,130 140,30" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <text x="125" y="150" font-size="14">base</text>
  <text x="145" y="25" font-size="14">A</text>
  <text x="28" y="135" font-size="14">B</text>
  <text x="225" y="135" font-size="14">C</text>
</svg>


If I needed $3$ tickets, put the vendors in order (cheapest first).
questions.answer:
- Super Tickets
- Ticket Galore
- Tickets R US
- Top Ticket

solutionDetails.working:
Let's calculate the best price of $3$ tickets from each vendor.

**Super Tickets**

The third ticket is free when you buy $2$ tickets. So, the cost of $3$ tickets is just the cost of $2$ tickets.

$
\begin  {aligned}
\text{Cost of } 3 \text{ tickets}     &= 480 \times 2 \\\\
                                      &= \pounds 960
\end{aligned}
$

**Tickets R US**

If the total price is reduced by $25 \%$, then the sale price will be $100 - 25 = 75 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Cost of} \ 3 \ \text{tickets}       &= 75\% \times 480 \times 3 \\\\
                                           &= \dfrac{75}{100} \times 480 \times 3 \\\\
                                           &= \dfrac{75 \times 480 \times 3}{100} \\\\
                                           &= \dfrac{25 \times 3 \times 4 \times 120 \times 3}{25 \times 4} \\\\
                                           &= \dfrac{\cancel{25} \times 3 \times \cancel{4} \times 120 \times 3}{\cancel{25} \times \cancel{4}} \\\\
                                           &= 3 \times 120 \times 3 \\\\
                                           &= \pounds 1080
\end{aligned}
$

**Ticket Galore**

If the price is reduced by $40 \%$, then the sale price will be $100 - 40 = 60 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Cost of} \ 3 \ \text{tickets}      &= 480 + 60\% \times 480 \times 2 \\\\
                                          &= 480 + \dfrac{60}{100} \times 480 \times 2 \\\\
                                          &= 480 + \dfrac{60 \times 480 \times 2}{100} \\\\
                                          &= 480 + \dfrac{6\cancel{0} \times 48\cancel{0} \times 2}{1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} \\\\
                                          &= 480 + 6 \times 48 \times 2 \\\\
                                          &= 480 + 576 \\\\
                                          &= \pounds 1056
\end{aligned}
$


**Top Ticket**

If the price is reduced by $\dfrac{1}{2}$, then the sale price will be $1 - \dfrac{1}{2} = \dfrac{1}{2}$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of} \ 3 \ \text{tickets}      &= 480 \times 2 + \dfrac{1}{2} \times 480 \\\\
                                         &= 960 + \dfrac{480}{2} \\\\
                                         &= 960 + \dfrac{240 \times 2}{2} \\\\
                                         &= 960 + \dfrac{240 \times \cancel{2}}{\cancel{2}} \\\\
                                         &= 960 + 240 \\\\
                                         &= \pounds 1200
\end{aligned}
$

Using the calculation above, the vendors in order (cheapest first):

|  Vendor       | Price          |
|:-------------:|:--------------:|
| Super Tickets | $\pounds 960$  |
| Ticket Galore | $\pounds 1056$ |
| Tickets R US  | $\pounds 1080$ |
| Top Ticket    | $\pounds 1200$ |

A teacher is making toffee apples for his class 'Hallowe'en party.

He needs to make $24$ toffee apples.

He uses the following recipe which makes $8$ toffee apples.

**Ingredients**

$8$ red apples

$400 \ \text{g}$ caster sugar

$1$ tsp lemon juice

$4$ tbsp golden syrup

red or black food colouring

children.prompt: How many tablespoons of golden syrup will he need?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the count of tablespoons needed $= a$

Using equivalent ratio,

$
\begin{aligned}
8 \ \text{toffee apples} : 4 \ \text{tbsp}      &= 24 \ \text{toffee apples} : a \ \text{tbsp} \\\\
\dfrac{8} {4}                                   &= \dfrac {24} {a} \\\\
8 \times a                                      &= 24 \times 4 \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {24 \times 4} {8} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {3 \times 8 \times 4} {8} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {3 \times \cancel {8} \times 4} {\cancel {8}} \\\\
a                                               &= 3 \times 4 \\\\
a                                               &= 12 \ \text{tbsp}
\end{aligned}
$

Golden syrup needed $= 12 \ \text{tbsp}$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**


Using ratios,

$
\begin{array}{cccccccccccccc}
  & \text{toffee apples}            &:&     \text{golden syrup} \\\\
= & 8                               &:&     4 \ \text{tbsp} \\\\
= & 8  \times 3                     &:&     4 \times 3 \\\\
= & 24                              &:&     12 \ \text{tbsp}
\end{array}
$

Golden syrup needed $= 12 \ \text{tbsp}$

questions.prompt: Arthur's twin sisters are $4 \ \text {years}$  older than him. Altogether their ages add up to $77$. How old is Arthur?

solutionDetails.working:
Let Arthur's age $= a$

His twin sisters' ages $= a + 4$ and $a + 4$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a + (a + 4) + (a + 4)   &= 77 \\\\
3a + 8                  &= 77 \\\\
3a                      &= 77 - 8 \\\\
3a                      &= 69 \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac{69}{3} \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac{23 \times 3}{3} \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac{23 \times \cancel{3}}{\cancel{3}} \\\\
a                       &= 23 \ \text{years}
\end{aligned}
$

questions.prompt:
Put these fractions in ascending order of size, show workings.

$\dfrac{3}{5}$ of $30$

$\dfrac{7}{10}$ of $20$

$\dfrac{2}{3}$ of $24$

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text {First} &= \dfrac{3}{5} \ \text{of} \ 30 \\\\
              &= \dfrac{3}{5} \times 30 \\\\
              &= \dfrac{3 \times 6 \times 5}{5} \\\\
              &= \dfrac{3 \times 6 \times \cancel{5}}{\cancel{5}} \\\\
              &= 18 \\\\
\text {Second}  &= \dfrac{7}{10} \ \text{of} \ 20 \\\\
                &= \dfrac{7}{10} \times 20 \\\\
                &= \dfrac{7 \times 20}{10} \\\\
                &= \dfrac{7 \times 2 \times 10}{10} \\\\
                &= \dfrac{7 \times 2 \times \cancel{10}}{\cancel{10}} \\\\
                &= 14 \\\\
\text {Third}  &= \dfrac{2}{3} \ \text{of} \ 24 \\\\
&= \dfrac{2}{3} \times 24 \\\\
&= \dfrac{2 \times 24}{3} \\\\
&= \dfrac{2 \times 8 \times 3}{3} \\\\
&= \dfrac{2 \times 8 \times \cancel{3}}{\cancel{3}} \\\\
&= 16
\end{aligned}
$

Arrange the results in ascending order.

$
\begin{aligned}
& 14 < 16 < 18 \\\\
& \dfrac{7}{10} \ \text{of} \ 20 < \dfrac{2}{3} \ \text{of} \ 24 < \dfrac{3}{5} \ \text{of} \ 30
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.

children.prompt:
Solve the following equation to find $b$.

$2b - 25 = 41$

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
2b - 25     &= 41 \\\\
2b          &= 41 + 25 \\\\
2b          &= 66 \\\\
b           &= \dfrac {66} {2} \\\\
b           &= \dfrac {33 \times 2} {2} \\\\
b           &= \dfrac {33 \times \cancel {2}} {\cancel {2}} \\\\
b           &= 33
\end{aligned}
$

What fraction of these numbers are below the median?

$2 \quad 7 \quad 10 \quad 5 \quad 4$

solutionDetails.working:
Let's arrange the numbers in ascending order.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Numbers} &= 2, \quad 7, \quad 10, \quad 5, \quad 4 \\\\
\text{Ordered numbers} &= 2, \quad 4, \quad \rtq_katex_color_info{5}, \quad 7, \quad 10 \\\\
\text{Median} &= 5
\end{aligned}
$

Numbers below the median are $2$ and $4$.

Fraction of numbers below the median $= \dfrac{2}{5}$

questions.prompt:
Given that two teas and a coffee cost $ \pounds 2.50$ and one tea and three coffees cost $ \pounds 3.50$.

How much does a single coffee cost?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the cost of a cup of tea $= t$

Let the cost of a cup of coffee $= c$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
2t + c &= 2.50 \\\\
t + 3c &= 3.50
\end{aligned}
$

We have got $2$ variables and we have $2$ equations to solve them. Let's eliminate to reduce it to just one variable.

Multiply the second equation by $2$.

$
\begin{aligned}
2 \times t + 2 \times 3c &= 2 \times 3.50 \\\\
2t + 6c &= 7.00
\end{aligned}
$

Subtract the first equation from the second to reduce it to one variable.

$
\begin{aligned}
(2t + 6c) - (2t + c) &= 7.00 - 2.50 \\\\
2t + 6c - 2t - c &= 4.50 \\\\
5c &= 4.50 \\\\
c &= \dfrac {4.50} {5} \\\\
c &= \pounds 0.90
\end{aligned}
$

Cost of a cup of coffee $= \pounds 0.90$.

questions.prompt:
A bridge is built across a river. One quarter of the bridge is over the left bank of the river and one third of the bridge is over the right bank.

The river is $84 \ \text{m}$ wide.

How long is the bridge?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the length of the bridge $= L \ \text{m}$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Portions over banks}  &= \dfrac{L}{4} + \dfrac{L}{3} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{3L}{4 \times 3} + \dfrac{4L}{3 \times 4} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{3L}{12} + \dfrac{4L}{12} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{7L}{12} \\\\
\text{Portion over river}   &= L - \dfrac{7L}{12} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{12L}{12} - \dfrac{7L}{12} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{5L}{12} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{5 \times 84}{12}  \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{5 \times 7 \times 12}{12}  \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{5 \times 7 \times \cancel{12}}{\cancel{12}}  \\\\
                            &= 35 \ \text{m}
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- When dividing by a fraction, multiply by the reciprocal.
- Write the final answer with the correct unit.

questions.prompt: Write down all the numbers between $50$ and $150$ that have an odd number of factors?

solutionDetails.working:
Let's list all the perfect squares between $50$ and $150$.

| Number | Calculation | Result |
|:------:|:-----------:|:-------:|
| $8$    | $8 \times 8$   | $64 < 150$ |
| $9$    | $9 \times 9$   | $81 < 150$ |
| $10$   | $10 \times 10$ | $100 < 150$ |
| $11$   | $11 \times 11$ | $121 < 150$ |
| $12$   | $12 \times 12$ | $144 < 150$ |
| $\rtq_katex_color_wrong_answer{13}$   | $\rtq_katex_color_wrong_answer{13 \times 13}$ | $\rtq_katex_color_wrong_answer{169 > 150}$ |

From the table above, all the perfect squares that are less than $150$ and greater than $50$ are $64, \ 81, \ 100, \ 121,$ and $144$.
